PER.basicGUI
Class BasicGUI

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Frame
                  javax.swing.JFrame
                      PER.basicGUI.BasicGUI
All Implemented Interfaces:
javax.accessibility.Accessible, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.swing.WindowConstants
public class BasicGUI
extends javax.swing.JFrame

BasicGUI is a graphical user interface for people wishing to program the Personal Exploration Rover (PER). BasicGUI provides some basic functionality, allowing programmers to design their own PER programs without the need to design a graphical interface.

The BasicGUI interface already provides a way for people to specify an IP address, connect to a rover, take and display pictures and panoramas, save images, and view text output from the rover.

BasicGUI also contains ten command buttons. The programmer can specify the commands associated with these buttons, as well as the button text, and an associated command description. There are also six input fields which can be used to specify variables used by the commands.

Each command button is already linked to a mouseListener, so pressing the button will launch the command. The programmer only needs to fill in the command method corresponding to the button they wish to use. For example, to program button1 to drive 50 cm, you could do something like the following: 

   private void command1() {
       //create a DriveToAction
       Action currAction = new DriveToAction(50);
       //execute the Action and print the results
       if(executeAction(currAction)){
           outputln("Drive successful");
       }else{
           outputln("Drive failed: "+ActionConstants.getErrorText(currAction.getReturnValue()));
       }
   }

The above code sample illustrates two other useful functions in BasicGUI: executeAction and outputln. executeAction is a blocking method for executing an Action. outputln will print a message to the output text area in the interface. Another useful function to be aware of is displayImage which will display an image in the interface and allow the image to be viewed at full resolution or scaled.

To program button1 to drive a variable distance based on user input, you could change the above example slightly: 

   private void command1() {
       //get the distance entered by the user in the X variable field
       int dist = intInput(variableX);
       //check that the input is valid
       if(inputIsValid()){
           Action currAction = new DriveToAction(dist);
           ...

The sample code above uses one of the variable input fields to determine the driving distance. Although text entered into a JTextField is always a string, BasicGUI provides convenience methods to allow you to convert the input into other data types and check if the input is valid.

When you have programmed a button for a certain task, you will also want to change the text displayed on that button and provide a description of the task. To do this, modify the lines for the button in setButtonText and setDescriptions. For our example that drives a variable distance based on input variable X, we might do something like this: 

  private void setButtonText(){
      button1.setText("Drive");
      ...

  private void setDescriptions(){
      description1.setText("Drive X cm");
      ...

One final feature of BasicGUI is the Stop button. If you use executeAction to execute Actions, the Stop button will work to kill these actions. If you use other Rover functions or the Action.doAction method to execute Actions, you will need to make sure that the Stop button still has the ability to kill these actions. For example, you may want to print a message while the rover is driving that tells how far it has traveled. 

   private void command1() {
       Action currAction = new DriveToAction(100);
       //start driving
       currAction.doAction(rov);
       //wait for the rover to finish driving
       while(!currAction.isCompleted()){
           outputln("Drove " + rov.highLevelState.getDist() + " cm.");
           try{
               Thread.sleep(100);
           }catch(java.lang.InterruptedException e){
               //stop driving if someone hits the stop button
               currAction.kill();
           }
       }
   }
The Stop button sets the stop variable to true so if you want the rover to do a dance until the Stop button is hit you could use a simple while loop such as: 
   private void command1() {
       while(!stop){
           //do a dance...
       }
   }
